title: 112_s1917
content:
The Act titled "Middle Class Tax Cut Act of 2011" includes temporary payroll tax relief for employers, employees, and the self-employed. During the payroll tax holiday period, the tax rate for remuneration received and paid will be 3.1 percent under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This applies to employees working for qualified employers. During the payroll tax holiday period, the tax rate for remuneration paid by qualified employers exempt from tax under section 501(a) will be 6.2 percent on the first $5 million of compensation subject to section 3111(a) or a corresponding amount subject to 3221(a). Self-employed individuals will also pay a 6.2 percent tax rate on net earnings during this period. During the payroll tax holiday period, self-employed individuals will pay a 6.2 percent tax rate on net earnings subject to section 1401(a) up to $5 million over total remuneration. Additionally, a 9.3 percent rate applies to any net earnings not subject to subsection (b)(1)(A) during this period. Deductions for employment taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be calculated differently for taxable years starting in the payroll tax holiday period. During the payroll tax holiday period, self-employed individuals will pay a 6.2 percent tax rate on net earnings subject to section 1401(a) up to $5 million over total remuneration. A 9.3 percent rate applies to any net earnings not subject to subsection (b)(1)(A) during this period. Deductions for employment taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be calculated differently for taxable years starting in the payroll tax holiday period. The deduction under section 164(f) of the Code is based on a percentage of the taxpayer's net earnings from self-employment. During the payroll tax holiday period in calendar year 2012, the Secretary may prescribe regulations for the allocation of excess funds among related taxpayers treated as a single qualified employer. A qualified employer is defined as any employer other than the United States, any State, or any political subdivision thereof. The term "qualified employer" includes public institutions of higher education. Aggregation rules apply to determine when multiple entities are treated as a single employer. Transfers of funds to federal old-age and survivors insurance are addressed. Transfers of funds are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury are transferred from the general fund to replicate transfers that would have occurred if certain amendments had not been enacted. Additionally, funds are appropriated to the Social Security equivalent benefit account. The Social Security Equivalent Benefit Account is appropriated amounts equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury due to the Railroad Retirement Tax. Transfers are made from the general fund to replicate the transfers that would have occurred without the amendments. The rate of tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is determined without considering the reduction in revenue. The rate of tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is determined without regard to the reduction in such rate under this section. SEC. 102. TEMPORARY TAX CREDIT FOR INCREASED PAYROLL. SEC. 102. TEMPORARY TAX CREDIT FOR INCREASED PAYROLL. Qualified employers are allowed a payroll increase credit for wages from October 1, 2011, through December 31, 2011, and January 1, 2012, through December 31, 2012, based on excess wages subject to tax. The Revenue Code of 1986 allows qualified employers a temporary tax credit for increased payroll based on excess wages subject to tax. If a qualified employer had zero wages subject to tax in 2010, the amount of wages for the credit is deemed to be 80 percent of the wages from October 1, 2011, through December 31, 2011. The subsection (a)(2) states that 80 percent of wages from 2012 will be considered if referred to. This subsection applies to employees working for qualified employers, excluding certain entities. Qualified employers are defined as any employer except for specific government entities. The term "qualified employer" includes public institutions of higher education. Aggregation rules similar to sections of the Internal Revenue Code apply to determine when multiple entities are treated as a single employer. The payroll increase credit is treated as a credit allowable under the Internal Revenue Code. The Code of 1986 allows for the amount treated for a specific period not to exceed the tax imposed on the qualified employer. Any income tax deduction for amounts paid under certain provisions will be reduced. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to cover revenue reductions. The amendments ensure transfers from the general fund replicate Trust Fund transfers. For railroad retirement taxes, certain sections apply with substitutions for employers under the Internal Revenue Code. TITLE II--SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES

SEC. 201. SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES. Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new part titled "SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES" with a new section imposing a surtax on millionaires. A surtax of 3.25 percent is imposed on taxpayers with modified adjusted gross income exceeding $1,000,000 ($500,000 for married individuals filing separately) for taxable years after 2012. Dollar amounts are adjusted for inflation annually starting from 2013. The section discusses the rounding of adjusted amounts to the nearest multiple of $10,000 and defines modified adjusted gross income as adjusted gross income minus certain deductions. Special rules apply for nonresident alien individuals. The section discusses the tax implications for citizens and residents living abroad, charitable trusts, and specifies that the tax imposed under this section is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes. The tax imposed under this section is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes. The amendment on surtax for millionaires will not change tax rates under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012.
